nodes.text: Contact comfort, rather than nursing or food provision, is the primary variable determining the development of affectionate bonds in neonatal and infant rhesus monkeys

Constructed surrogate mothers: a cloth-covered, warm, soft terry cloth surrogate with a single artificial breast, and a wire-mesh surrogate warmed by radiant heat, to isolate contact comfort from nursing

Experimental design: dual-mother condition with cloth and wire surrogates placed in attached cubicles; counterbalanced lactation (for four infants cloth lactated, for four infants wire lactated); time spent on each surrogate automatically recorded; supplementary behavioral tests included fear stimuli, open-field with and without mother, modified Butler box visual preference tests, and retention tests over months
Control conditions included single-cloth-mother and single-wire-mother rearing groups and a control group with no surrogate until 250 days, to compare nursing, contact, and late introduction effects

Assumption and context: prevailing psychological theory treated love as a derived drive secondary to primary drives like hunger, with mother becoming a conditioned reinforcer through feeding; the experimental program challenges this assumption
Result: Across conditions, infant monkeys spent substantially more time clinging to the cloth surrogate than the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk

Result: Infants with lactating wire mothers decreased responsiveness to the wire mother and increased responsiveness to the nonlactating cloth mother with age, contradicting derived-drive conditioning explanations

Result: In fear tests and open-field tests, infants consistently sought the cloth surrogate as a haven of safety and used it as a secure base for exploration; nursing condition did not affect this preference

Result: Single-wire-mother reared infants and single-cloth-mother reared infants did not differ in milk intake or weight gain, but wire-mother infants produced softer stools, suggesting psychosomatic effects of inadequate contact comfort

Result: Control infants introduced to cloth and wire surrogates at 250 days initially showed fear and avoidance but within days developed strong contact with the cloth surrogate, though peak contact time was lower than animals mothered from birth

Evidence: Modified Butler box and visual preference tests showed high responding to the cloth mother and other infants, little or no greater responsiveness to the wire mother than an empty box, and preferences persisted in repeated tests

Evidence: Retention tests over 185 days showed persistent and significant differential responding favoring the cloth surrogate versus wire surrogate or empty box, indicating long-term stability of the affectional bond

Conclusion: Contact comfort is an overwhelming and primary affectional variable for infant monkeys, produces security and exploratory benefits, is largely independent of nursing, generalizes to late attachment though intensity may be reduced, and yields long-lasting bonds resistant to extinction
